subtitle: [Music]
Thinking Allowed. Conversations on the
leading edge of knowledge and discovery with psychologist Jeffrey Mishlove. Hello
and welcome. I'm Jeffrey Mishlove. Today we are going to look at near-death
experience and how one integrates it into their life. With me is Dr. Eben
Alexander who is the author of several books
including Proof of Heaven, The Map of Heaven and,
co-authored with Karen Newell, Living in a Mindful Universe. Dr. Alexander is a
former professor of Neurosurgery at Harvard Medical School.
Welcome, Eben. Jeff, thanks for having me. It's great to be
here. It's a pleasure to be with you. Your book Proof of Heaven
has been a best-seller now for quite a long time. Millions
of copies have been sold, people all over the world are aware
of the near-death experience that you had. I'm sure the fact that you
entered into this experience as a materialistic scientist, as a
neurosurgeon makes your story even more compelling. But
I think what's interesting today to focus on is what
it's like for you looking back on that experience after ten years. How has it
been to integrate that experience because it changed
your life dramatically. It changed everything
really. I had to go back to square one in terms of my
understanding of the nature of reality. As much as people kind of
marvel at the fact that a Harvard neurosurgeon would go through such an
extraordinary kind of process of a near-death experience and come back with
this kind of story, to them they seem like, oh my gosh, how in the
world does that kind of a coincidence happen? And yet for me it was
simply the soul journey that one would expect.
It is important to point out that near-death
experiences, in spite of the fact that they have tremendous commonalities which
basically indicate that they're referring to one very
real realm and that is independent of one’s prior
religious beliefs, what country you grew up in, or even what millennia you live in.
It's astonishing but there's a commonality. In addition each NDE is
tailor made for the soul undergoing it. And so for me looking back on it
it's perfectly natural that for kind of a hardcore materialist neuroscientists
like myself who fully believed the brain creates
consciousness of course I would have an NDE that would show me
kind of the bright edges and reality around my knowledge base and lead me
into a deeper understanding of something about which I've
had a passionate interest my whole life and that is kind
of a deeper understanding of the nature of reality, the
relationship between mind and brain, and in fact therefore the
fundamental nature of conscious awareness itself. So
it was really tailor made to me but of course I never
read the near-death experience literature before so I had no idea of
those commonalities. I had always just thought it's a trick of the dying brain so
what do they matter? Of course then having my own was a mind bender and as
expected, as being part of the personal message, it also involved a disease that
was in many ways a perfect model for human death. For a neuroscientist
interested in understanding brain-mind consciousness you
couldn't imagine anything more perfect than a severe case
of bacterial meningoencephalitis because what that does is it's like a laboratory
prep, it's a perfect model for systematically dismantling kind of the
primary engine of detailed conscious awareness according to modern neuroscience.
Modern neuroscience would tell you that our neocortex, as the most powerful
calculator in the human brain, one that is absolutely according to their
view involved with all of the detailed conscious awareness
of everything we've ever experienced, everything that we see,
everything we hear, all of our thoughts, the language in our mind, our
kind of rational thinking, our sense of free will and of executive function
and of perception of body in space—every bit of that kind of detailed awareness
depends on some part of the neocortex still working. That's why my gram
negative bacterial meningitis with all the neurological evidence
my doctors had of the destruction not only of my neocortex
but even of my brain stem from day one. I mean, this was a very severe case.
Also the scans, the CT and MRI scans, revealed
that it was a full thickness destruction, that
I had swelling all the way down to below the six layers of my neocortex to
where they intersect with the white matter. In effect,
it's a miracle you're alive. Let's put it this way.
My doctors estimated when I first got to that emergency room seizing and in
coma on that Monday morning, November 10th of 2008, that I had a 10% chance of
survival. So that's not a miracle, that's a 10% chance. By
the end of the week I was down to a 2% chance of survival. But
then they never thought you would fully recover. See, that's
the part that really is miraculous and that my doctors
to this day would tell you is inexplicable based on Western medicine.
Basically, even when I woke up in the ICU bed on day seven of
coma… Waking up is not really the right word to use because in fact when I
woke up all I remembered was my near-death experience,
that incredible spiritual journey I had been on. But one
anomaly of my experience is the fact that I was amnesic.
I didn't remember anything of Eben Alexander's life. In
fact during the entire coma experience I had no words or language at all. When
I did wake up that day seven of coma in that
ICU bed with my mother, my sisters, my former
spouse, my sons at the bedside, I had no idea who these beings were, that's how
kind of wrecked my mind was. But soon after that they
extubated me and my words and language were coming back very
quickly. Within a day or two I was recognizing people quite readily.
In fact, I realized that the six faces that I described seeing towards the end
of my near-death experience who I didn't recognize at the
time, who would kind of visualize out of the muck and utter a
few sounds that I couldn't interpret and then disappear again,
five of those were people who were physically present in
the ICU room the last 24 hours of coma. Notably there were many family and
friends who had been there earlier in the week who I did
not remember at all. So in fact those five faces that
occurred at the very end of my conscious awareness of the experience helped to
frame that the vast majority of the coma experience happened between days one and
five when my doctors knew full well from my neurologic exams that my Glasgow Coma
Scale, which normally ranges from three in a corpse to fifteen in a normally
waking person, with any score below nine being
deep coma, well those five days when I had all the
experience my Glasgow Coma Scale was between five and seven. So I was in a very
deep coma. They knew from the scans that the entire neocortex
was involved. That's the part that is miraculous, that all
of it came back within really two months after coma, all my memories. In fact, my
memories came back and I realized in conversations with
family and friends over the next year or two that the
memories were more complete after they returned. To me
it was a very strong indicator that memory is not even
stored in the brain. That's something that we cover in
detail in the third book, Living in a Mindful Universe.
It's kind of a shocking reality to modern neuroscientists but neurosurgeons
have suspected for a long time that memories don't seem to be resident in
the brain because mainly in spite of the millions of neocortical resections—
a removal of brain tissue we've done for tumors, vascular
lesions, all that kind of thing over the last century—you never
have a case where you have a broad swathe of identifiable
long-term memories that seem to be deleted by that
kind of brain resection. So it doesn't seem that physical memory is there in
the brain at all. It's just that our brain serves as an
access point to both consciousness and memory. But that is the
part that my doctors would tell you today is an absolute
miracle that I could have any experience at all and
that to me was the shocker. When I first came back of course
I had no idea how sick I had been so I assumed given that
it was way too real to be real that it had to be a vast hallucination. But then
as I went back over the next weeks and months reviewing
my medical records, my scans, talking it all over with my
neurologists and with the other doctors, I started realizing
the medical records I was reviewing were those of somebody
destined to die, certainly not someone who would have a
profound experience and then come back and tell the world about
it. That's where I think my story really garnered significant interest in
the scientific and medical community and that's why I've been
asked to give talks to medical and surgical and nursing groups
around the world because they recognized the kind of impossibility that I faced
in trying to explain my experience against the setting
of my medical records which suggested that it was
impossible. To my understanding the brain of an adult human being doesn't
regenerate itself, like the whole neocortex, that's not known. In a
child I'm told the brain is very plastic. Right.
That's very true. Neuroplasticity, the ability of new
neurons to form and form new connections and all that, is certainly more robust in
children than in adults. When I trained—I finished
medical school in 1980, my residency in 1987—back in
those days we really didn't believe there was any
significant neuroplasticity in adult brains. But
we've since discovered that is just not true.
People can manifest quite extraordinary modes
of recovery. My case is one example even though it still is
something where most doctors would consider miraculous
that I spent seven days in coma due to severe bacterial
meningoencephalitis. Especially a gram-negative which is
the worst kind you can have, even to the point where my
cerebral spinal fluid glucose level which normally
would be 60-80 and somebody with a very bad
meningitis might go down as low as 20, in my case it
went to one. None of my doctors or their consultants
had ever seen a meningitis case that severe. That's why I think my doctors
to this day, in spite of the fact that, yes, a 2% chance of
recovery is not a miracle, it's a 2% chance, you know one in
fifty. But to recover, that part is really astonishing. They expected,
as I recall, towards the end of the coma that if you recovered at all,
which was unlikely, that you would be spending the rest of
your life in a nursing home. That's correct. They didn't
expect any chance of recovering mental function, in other
words no quality of life. That's why on that seventh day,
that morning, seventh day of coma they had just had a family conference where
they reiterated that things just had not worked out well, that I'd been on
three very powerful intravenous antibiotics for the week, I'd been on
the ventilator all week long, but my neurologic condition was really not
improving at all. They thought it would be smarter just to
let nature take its course. The recommendation there was
that it was time to stop the antibiotics. It was a few hours
later that I came back to this world. But again as I said
my doctors were no fools. When I came back my brain was
absolutely wrecked by the experience. It took months for
you to really… It did take two months for everything to
come back. I would say for the first week or two it was very
frightening for my family to witness because they thought, “Oh, this wonderful
miracle, he's coming back to us, but oh my
god, he's totally wrecked, this is horrible, it
would have been better for him to go on and die.” That's why the doctors had
recommended that course. And yet my recovery was so extraordinary. I just
kind of came rocketing out of that to a point where I could even
discuss and review my medical records with my doctors
within a month or so, which to them was an absolute shocker.
Because immediately when you came out of the coma I gather
you were rather delirious. Yes, I was in fact. That's a
beautiful part of the story that I share in Proof of Heaven. After they
extubated me at the very earliest of my kind of waking up, I
really don't remember that. I was told by my family that I was sitting there on
the bed like this little Buddha and I was saying, “All is well. Don't worry. All
is well.” Now, I do not remember saying those words but
there were many witnesses and I'm sure I said it with
utter conviction. But the upshot is even though I had
been extubated and they thought I was waking up I was
kind of in and out of a wild kind of delusional paranoid nightmare.
The interesting thing is even in the midst of that crazy kind of 36 hours of
in and out of the nightmare I knew that that was a
delusion. I knew it wasn't real. There were parts of it
that seemed very real and it took a little convincing
from my family. For example, part of that kind of delusion
state had to do with the fact that I was in a cancer ward, a cancer hospital in south
Florida, three adjacent buildings with these escalators coming
up through it. I can remember it now. It's kind of a foggy
memory of things even though at the time it seemed pretty
real. You were in Virginia. But I was in Virginia. I was
actually in Virginia. And that's the part where my family
challenged me on, and especially challenged me on how
I got there. I knew the system that had got me there in
this crazy nightmare was a made up system of underground tubes and trains.
I remember this elaborate system of getting me there. But the interesting thing
is compared to the memories from deep coma, the spiritual
journey that I reported in Proof of Heaven that happened
when I had a documented Glasgow Coma Scale of six to seven, deep coma,
documented CT and MRI evidence that all eight lobes of my brain had full
thickness inflammation from this destructive, and should
have killed me, bacterial meningitis, those memories are
sharp and clear, as sharp today as if they happened yesterday, the deep coma
memories. Whereas those kind of paranoid delusional ICU psychosis memories of the
south Florida cancer clinic and these tube trains underground,
all that kind of wildness I knew was a hallucination.
So they're very different. I've since discovered several scientific
papers from doctors who study NDEs where they look at the quality of
memories over time from a near-death experience versus
dreams or psychedelic drug experiences, other imaginatory
experiences or real life experiences like a car wreck
or something that really sticks in your mind. The
interesting thing that these scientists have uncovered
about near-death experiences, including scientists both in
the US and in Europe, is that the near-death memories are far more stable
and resilient over time. That's something that makes
perfect sense to me because I've given more than four
hundred talks to audiences around the world about my
experience and I very often have people coming up to me after
these talks, many of whom are completely naive to the NDE literature, and they
will come up and say, “I've never told anybody this before but…” and then they'll
share a story with me that happened to them. It
could have happened 60 years ago and yet they claim
to remember it as clearly as if it just happened yesterday.
These stories are very extraordinary. They are not
hallucinations. They are not dreams. They're not the effect of drugs unless
you have documented evidence of a certain
psychomimetic kind of drug that's on board at the time.
In fact, there's recently been a case report on my medical records that
I think is very important for this world because there was a lay press article
about my case that was completely erroneous and misinterpreted many facts
of my life and was basically an ad hominem attack. That article
tried to portray that I was in a coma only because of
pharmacologic manipulation. It failed to acknowledge that
I was in deep coma from the moment that I was taken by
the EMTs from my home. I was in deep coma already long
before any IVs or drugs went in and stayed in that coma all week long, and in
fact was still on very heavy sedation when I came out of coma.
But anyway, that case report will come out. It's authored
by Bruce Grayson and his co investigators at UVA. It'll come out in
the Journal of Nervous and Mental Diseases in September of 2018, so
that's immediately upon us. It makes a very clear case
that I was in deep coma due to severe brain damage from
meningitis. The reason that's important to the medical
community is because a coma, because of destruction of
the neocortex, should get rid of any hallucination, dream or drug effect
of conscious awareness because of that global destruction of the neocortex.
One of the unique features that you described and I haven't encountered this
in other accounts of near-death experience is that
when you first in effect arrived in this alternative
reality you found yourself sort of embedded in an unpleasant muck of
some sort. It sounds foreboding and kind of unpleasant but given that
I was totally amnesiac, this is like my birth
into the universe as an awareness. I had no
memories of Earth or humanity or being Eben Alexander. None
of the words or language, religious concepts, none of the
scientific knowledge, none of that made it
through. That tabula rasa or empty slate I think
was very important for the journey I had to go through. That
only became clear in the months and years after the coma,
just how critical that empty slate was. But that was part of the
teaching about the brain-mind connection and about the nature
of consciousness, was the fact that I had to delete all
memories in a sense to go through it all. Then of course the
fact that all my memories came back even better than they
were before in the eight months after coma. But I think that empty slate was
very important. It all started with what I call the
earthworm's eye view, like being in dirty jello. Even though I
had no body awareness during any part of the journey I was a piece
of awareness and I could sense around me. I remember roots
or blood vessels, something that was just everywhere.
Given that I had no memory moment-to-moment it seemed
to go for eons. But it didn't, it ended because
there came this slowly spinning very clear white light that had fine silvery
and golden tendrils off of it. As that white light came
towards me one of the most beautiful aspects of it is it came
packaged with a perfect musical melody. The notes of that melody proved
crucial. Just as human beings have used sound for tens of
thousands of years to get into altered states of conscious
awareness. For example, the didgeridoo, which I think is one of the
most healing musical instruments on earth, supposedly has been around for
40,000 years. Sound, vibration,
frequency not only works to take us out of the four-dimensional
space-time of this very dense material realm to help
liberate our conscious awareness but also sound serves as kind of a vehicle
for traversal of multiple spiritual realms. That's what
I first learned with that spinning melody of light that
ushered me up out of that utterly earthworm eye view
realm into this beautiful gateway valley that in many
ways was much more real this world. It was a world with beautiful lush plant growth
everywhere and all of it growing very dynamic and actively
growing. There were no signs of death or decay anywhere.
I remember sparkling blue water falls into these crystal blue pools.
There were thousands of beings down below us all
dancing. When I came back to this world and tried to put
words to it and tried to write all this down I labeled those as souls between
lives. They were dressed in a kind of very simple, kind
of peasant garb and beautiful colors, colors beyond the
rainbow. There was lots of joy and merriment going on.
There were children playing and dogs jumping, incredible
festivities down below. I was witnessing it because I was a speck of
awareness on a butterfly. On this butterfly wing there were millions of
other butterflies and they were looping and spiraling in
these vast formations. I remember witnessing all that and
the reason all this was so natural and seemed perfectly real to me was because
up above were these swooping orbs, golden orbs of light, each one seeming
to be a pure spiritual essence and they were leaving these
sparkling golden trails against this blue black velvety
sky. The entire scene was just lit by these billowing
clouds of pure color. But these swooping orbs up
above were emanating chants and anthems and hymns that would just thunder through my
awareness and just resonate this incredible power of
oneness, of identification. It's one of the reasons
why it's so difficult to explain these journeys. We're not
just seeing with the eyes or hearing with the ears which
are very kind of filtered and limited sensory modalities. In
these spiritual realms we become all of it. You can essentially see through
everything because you're becoming it and forming this
beautiful model of all of it that transcends four-dimensional
space-time. It's an extremely elaborate form of
knowing. It's amazing you can put it into words at all.
I wrestled and struggled with the words in Proof of
Heaven trying to get it right. At the end of the day I
finally felt like the words were about as good as the
words I could do. I often feel that way in some of my
discussions of it in presentations and interviews
and conferences. But in fact you're absolutely right.
You cannot put it into words. That's one of the
reasons why I think people also confuse… There
are a lot of people out there these days who say, “Oh,
sounds like a DMT trip,” dimethyltryptamine, which is a
hallucinogen that purportedly is found in minute amounts
in human beings although that is somewhat up to debate.
But the reality is the words may sound the same but the
words are not really describing the fullness of the journey.
So I would just caution you to know that this is much more
than a psychedelic drug trip in terms of its reality, in terms
of its meaning. In fact there have been direct comparisons
of that in the scientific literature and they basically
find that all the transcendental aspects of a near-death
experience, like encountering souls of departed loved ones
and that full-blown oneness with the power of pure love at
the creative source of the universe, and a lot about life mission and seeing
one's future, things like that, aren't as readily apparent
in a psychedelic drug trip but they certainly come through
in robust fashion in the more profound near-death experiences.
There was also, if I recall, a timeless quality, it
felt like you might have been there for years. It actually
triggered off a tremendous interest I have in the nature
of time. The one thing that became very clear to me is
that what we see as past, present, future is very much a fiction. In fact, when
you get into conventional science, whether you're talking
about relativity and the way it looks at time and how time
and space are interchangeable, or you look at
quantum physics and the way that it kind of portrays
basically a time flow that can go in loops, really the only
thing that gives us a direction of time in our human kind
of macro sized world, halfway between the size of a
quark or an electron and a galaxy, is the second law
of thermodynamics which is a statistical law that simply
talks about order and disorder in large numbers of particles.
That's what basically gives us an arrow of time. But other than that in
terms of our world of physics, time should easily flow
both directions and yet we always seem to have this sense
that it only goes in one direction. In my journey I had to even label
something that I call deep time. I've heard the phrase deep time used by
others in slightly different ways but I think all of us are
trying to converge on the notion. For me, deep time is a
completely different ordering of causality that you have to invoke in connecting to
those realms. For example, that gateway valley was
only a stepping stone on my way out. Of course, we can
discuss more about that stepping stone and where it was leading. That would
be the same realm where we go through life reviews, where
we reunite with our higher soul at the time of leaving the
physical body. The life review is very important. It's
been described by near-death experiencers going back at
least 2,400 years. Plato writes about the Armenian soldier, Er, killed in
battle. He was out dead on the battlefield for several
days before they finally collected all the bodies and put
him on a funeral pyre. Just before they lit it Er came back to life.
Essentially, the journey he portrayed is that
when you die you go through a review of the most
important and kind of pertinent lessons still to be learned.
So if you're one of those who handed out pain and suffering
to others as soldiers often do, you've got to be ready to face that. We
reap what we sow. In essence, the life review is a beautiful example of how the
boundaries of self are a fiction. They support the drama of this world where we
have apparent separation of self from other
self. And yet in a life review you experience the
impact not only of your actions but even of your thoughts on those around you and
you experience it as they experience it. That's why it's
such a good course corrective to help us learn to treat
others. This was part of your experience. It was part
of the experience. That's why we should treat others
as we would like to be treated. I mean, you could almost look
at it as a neutral ground even though in that life review
setting it's in that infinite ocean of pure unconditional love of that
god force that of course is what so many near-death
experiencers bring back to this world and know full well in
their own heart, in their emotional state, there's nothing
to fear about death because it's a reuniting with that ocean
of absolute warmth and love and kindness and compassion and mercy of that
creative source of this universe. The idea that you
are experiencing the pain and also the joy that you
are responsible for in other people but experiencing it through their eyes,
their feelings. Their feelings. Their heart.
That's a good reason to remember to treat others
as we would like to be treated. It also suggests that at
some level of our consciousness we are everyone. We are,
absolutely. I think that is something that we make a very clear
point of in our third book, Living in a Mindful Universe. It was clear to me in
my coma journey that we're really sharing one mind,
that when we die it's basically like a raindrop falling
back into the ocean, in a sense. Although it's also interesting that there's this
tremendous body of evidence concerning reincarnation and scientific
study of reincarnation. So it's not really a question of whether or not you want
to believe it or if your religious texts support it, most religious texts do. In
fact, original Christianity fully supports
reincarnation. Christ talking about the prophet who was
reincarnated as John the Baptist. But it was actually
Constantine several centuries later who made any talk of
reincarnation punishable by inverted crucifixion. He didn't
like that idea because of how it interfered with their
ability to control people with what they were putting
together at the Council of Nicaea and that kind of thing,
codifying and unifying Christian religious thought.
But certainly, reincarnation is completely compatible
with early Christianity and other phases. And then the
scientific evidence that supports it today. For any of
your listeners who are interested I would steer them to, I think it's UVA DOPS,
which is the Division of Perceptual Studies at the University of Virginia under the
guidance initially of Ian Stevenson back in the 60s, 70s, 80s, more recently of Dr.
Jim Tucker. They've studied more than 2700 cases. We've done extensive
interviews on that here on this channel. Now let
me ask you this question because you spent your
whole life as a materialistic scientist. Now you've had this incredible
experience and you're coming out of it but you also have a lifetime of habits
of thinking differently. It must have taken you a while to absorb all of
this to come to the realizations that you now have.
They didn't happen overnight. It didn't, you're right.
Yes, it really took going back to square one. I
had to question everything going back to the very
beginning. That includes any of the assumptions I had
about the nature of reality. One of the most fundamental
assumptions in conventional materialist neuroscience is that only the physical
world exists. If only the physical world exists then somehow you've got to
come up with a way to explain consciousness and
mind based on the physical workings of the brain.
That's where it hits an absolute wall. Back in the mid-1990s David Chalmers
wrote his book, The Conscious Mind, which was really a consolidation of several
decades of work from around the world that were pointing out the lapses that
all the workings of the brain do not explain the workings of the mind. In fact,
I very much revere the work of Wilder
Penfield. He was one of the most renowned neurosurgeons of the 20th century. He was
Canadian, worked out of Montreal and he is in a better
position than just about anybody on earth to comment around the
brain-mind connection because a lot of his work involved electrically
stimulating the brain in awake patients. He was a neurosurgeon
like yourself. A neurosurgeon who dealt with epilepsy. That was
one of his big topics. To resect the part of the brain that causes the
epilepsy often you have to map it out. It turns out the brain
feels no pain at all. I've done several hundred of those cases
myself, awake craniotomies in patients where you map out the brain by
electrically stimulating and then having the patient
report to you what kind of memory or sensation they
have during that electrical stimulation. Initially Penfield
thought he was hot on the trail of uncovering the source of
memory but then he came to realize, well, even if he resected
a part of the brain that he thought contained the memory,
that that memory could still be very robust in that patient.
So he realized it wasn't so simple. In fact, he wrote a
book in 1975 that summarized his life experience in such cases. That book is
called The Mystery of the Mind. In that book he makes it
clear time after time after time all throughout the book
that you cannot explain mind and consciousness based simply on the
workings of the brain. Not only that you would never find
anything resembling freewill in the brain itself, that
consciousness and freewill—and he was extrapolating to
the point of saying memory too because he eliminated the
possibility that memory seemed to be in the
neocortex. But generally, the profession as much as
they revere Wilder Penfield they didn't follow
him that far. It's a real tragedy. We actually met
one of his team in Montreal who had been involved in his medical care who said
that when he published that book it was a year before he died of cancer and that
the kind of story on the streets there at
the Montreal Neurological Institute was that
basically the cancer had influenced his thinking. So it
was a very kind of cheap cop-out. Anybody who reads the
book will realize his thinking was not at all impaired.
It's a very insightful reflective book. I've read a lot of
his other work around that time, the foundational work from
the 1940s and 50s and his scientific papers that led to
those conclusions. He was very clear of mind and couldn't have been clearer on
an interpretation of the data. And yet the world, the
scientific world in particular, was not ready to hear in 1975
that the brain was not the producer of consciousness.
You got trained as a neurosurgeon after that.
You had no problem, I imagine, assuming that consciousness was a product of the
brain. That's what I was taught and that's what I
believed. The important thing to point out is that if
we take that supposition and then we go to a modern neuroscientist or
philosopher of mind and we ask them, oh, the brain produces consciousness, tell me
more. They won't have anything to say. There is nothing there. There are some
vague kinds of theoretical models that talk about information processing and
information ordering and make some big assumptions
about how that might somehow work in the brain. But
in terms of actually having any notion whatsoever about how the neurons in the
brain, the hundred billion nerve cells in the brain interacting give rise to
consciousness, nobody has the remotest clue. I have heard speculation about
neural loops and cybernetic feedback loops within the nervous system.
It's about as close as I've ever heard. They have some working models that seem
to be kind of okay at their very primitive level.
Those models basically involve as I mentioned earlier
the neocortex as the main calculator, that's by far the
most powerful calculator in the brain. In fact, it's
amazing how those six cell layers in the neocortex have been modified to
do so many functions. Everything that we see, everything that we hear, our
body position in space. All of what I see out there,
